title: There's A Durga In All Of Us: School Students Recreate Avatar Of Durga Complete With The Lion
text:
There's A Durga In All Of Us: School Students Recreate Avatar Of Durga Complete With The Lion

There's A Durga In All Of Us: School Students Recreate Avatar Of Durga Complete With The Lion

The festival season is ongoing and Durga maa is being adorned and praised all across the country. While Bengalis celebrate Durga Pujo with lavishly decorated pandals and Durga Idols, in Gujarat, garba nights are a must.

The word Durga, from the root word 'durgam', itself means fearlessness. To be able to face each adversity, however big or small it may be, makes us who we are. Durga maa, with her eight hands, epitomizes the word 'multi-tasking’ and it celebrates each and every woman who is a Durga in her own right.

Twitter

Goddess Durga comes to us in nine different avatars (forms) on the nine days of Navratri, and each and every form is in all of us. It defines our everyday lives and celebrates our trials, tribulations and joys, as humans.

In the classic Durga representative image, she is committing the vadh of a daitya, while her savari, the lion lies in front of her. This larger than life portrait of maa Durga was recreated by a bunch of Indian students in some corner of the country.

Raveena Tondon shared the picture with the caption, ‘So far the sweetest picture and portrayal of Ma Durga Devi by kids that I’ve seen on the net. Adorable . Jai Mata Di’.

So far the sweetest picture and portrayal of Ma Durga Devi by kids that I’ve seen on the net. Adorable . Jai Mata Di 🙏🏻🕉🙏🏻 pic.twitter.com/UtLMxqY3cN — Raveena Tandon (@TandonRaveena) October 7, 2019

In some cultures, little girls (kanya) are hailed as the avatars of Goddess Durga and are worshipped on the 8th (Ashtmi) and the 9th (navmi) day of the navratras.

The little girl along with her friends is surely recreating the classic image of the goddess and indeed, is a Durga in her own right.
